text: I've been happy with Ipopt and Knitro, though Knitro is not free. Are those not good enough for what you need?

elements.text: I've been happy with Ipopt and Knitro, though Knitro is not free. Are those not good enough for what you need?

text:
Trajectory Optimization is a quiet sparse problem, so i searched for a solver that is "spasity first". I never actually benchmarked Worhp against Ipopt as the interface is quiet inconvinient. (The easiest way to benchmark it would be to wrap it in JuMP)
I had some probelms with Ipopt

I am not sure what you mean by "sparsity first". WORHP does seem interesting. Maybe you can initiate a WORHP.jl package. :slightly_smiling_face: I have not wrapped anything with Julia before, but many people in the Julia community have done it for other solvers.

elements.text: I am not sure what you mean by "sparsity first". WORHP does seem interesting. Maybe you can initiate a WORHP.jl package.
I have not wrapped anything with Julia before, but many people in the Julia community have done it for other solvers.

text: I am curious: which problems did you meet with Ipopt?

elements.text: I am curious: which problems did you meet with Ipopt?

text: <https://github.com/freemin7/WorhpOpt.jl> I am on it. I have a local branch which is further ahead but still doesn't have JuMP support
Ipopt was to slow and failed to converge in some cases
Worhp seems more robust, but maybe a bit slower than IPOPT from these benchmarks. <http://plato.asu.edu/ftp/ampl-nlp.html>

Ipopt─just like any other solver, really─requires some exploration of the user options available, which are usually problem-specific. For a given set of options, just because they work well for solving a small and dense problem it does not mean that they will translate well when trying to solve other classes of problems, e.g., large and sparse. But I am quite sure you know that.

elements.text: Ipopt─just like any other solver, really─requires some exploration of the user options available, which are usually problem-specific. For a given set of options, just because they work well for solving a small and dense problem it does not mean that they will translate well when trying to solve other classes of problems, e.g., large and sparse. But I am quite sure you know that.

text:
For the kind of problems I try to solve (large and very sparse) I found that the most important settings are (in order):
1. algorithm
2. linear solver
3. barrier parameter update strategy
For (1) I use interior-point methods; anyway, you only have to consider options of (1) if you have a choice (e.g., in Knitro you can choose between interior-point methods and active-set methods, but I think for Ipopt there's only one method available AFAIK).

For (2), I usually go with HSL MA57. MA27 is a bit slow and outdated.

For (3), which is only relevant for barrier methods, I go with "adaptive" updates. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: For the kind of problems I try to solve (large and very sparse) I found that the most important settings are (in order):

For (1) I use interior-point methods; anyway, you only have to consider options of (1) if you have a choice (e.g., in Knitro you can choose between interior-point methods and active-set methods, but I think for Ipopt there's only one method available AFAIK).

For (2), I usually go with HSL MA57. MA27 is a bit slow and outdated.

For (3), which is only relevant for barrier methods, I go with "adaptive" updates.

text: When I started working with numerical optimisation, I was astonished by how much of a difference choosing a non-default user-option can make!

elements.text: When I started working with numerical optimisation, I was astonished by how much of a difference choosing a non-default user-option can make!

text: (Now I am a bit sad these messages will disappear in 10 days, as they could be useful for future reference by other people. :disappointed:)

elements.text: (Now I am a bit sad these messages will disappear in 10 days, as they could be useful for future reference by other people.

text: I will probably write a blog post about these hands-on "findings" in the future. I do have most of them in the papers I write, but I am sure the amount of people a concise blog post can reach is far greater than scientific papers behind paywalls.

text: I have been using Zulip, but usually people come here (to Slack) with robotics questions. Maybe it's time we start (nicely) asking people to post their questions on Zulip whenever they post something here in the future.
